definition: rumors and slanders (idiom); gossip/lies and slanders
to flow/to disseminate/to circulate or spread/to move or drift/to degenerate/to banish or send into exile/stream of water or sth resembling one/class, rate or grade
words/speech/to say/to talk
gad-fly
dialect/language/speech
to tell to

sentences.english: Love really need courage to face the tattle and prate.
sentences.chinese: 愛真的需要勇氣，來面對流言蜚語。

sentences.english: He doesn't care about scandals, slanders, calumnies, aspersions, or defamation.
sentences.chinese: 他不在乎流言蜚語，誹謗，中傷。

sentences.english: Even just passing gossip and hearsay can prime your mind for illness with potent effect.
sentences.chinese: 哪怕只傳傳流言蜚語和道聽途說都能灌輸強烈影響。

sentences.english: But there is more to me than just a tabloid girl.
sentences.chinese: 但是總有一些很過分的流言蜚語加諸在我身上。

sentences.english: The circulation of gossip is vicious.
sentences.chinese: 傳播流言蜚語是可惡的。

sentences.english: THE GIST Gossiping can be beneficial.
Disordered nerves and bad digestion are a common cause of backbiting.
sentences.chinese: 神經過敏和承擔力差是生成流言蜚語的常見原因。

sentences.english: He discredited my good name with gossip.
sentences.chinese: 他用流言蜚語敗壞我的好名聲。

sentences.english: He was bespattered by malicious gossip .
sentences.chinese: 流言蜚語者惡毒的舌頭。

sentences.english: She discredited him with ugly gossip.
sentences.chinese: 她用難聽的流言蜚語臭他。

sentences.english: Discourage gossip, and don't put people in the position of spying or reporting on each other.
sentences.chinese: 制止流言蜚語，不要讓人做臥底或者打小報告。

sentences.english: The Palace won't like all this gossip.
sentences.chinese: 國王不會喜歡這些流言蜚語的。

sentences.english: He scattered imputations at large against my reputation.
sentences.chinese: 他到處散佈流言蜚語，毀壞我的名聲。

sentences.english: The rumors and slanders is negligible to me.
sentences.chinese: 流言蜚語對於我來說是可以忽略的。

sentences.english: Somebody gossiped that she grabbed at the opportunity of becoming famous.
sentences.chinese: 一些人流言蜚語說她抓住了成名的機會。

definition: variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
to gesticulate/to point out/to point the finger of blame
to think highly of oneself (idiom); giving oneself airs/arrogant and self-important
to harbor evil designs/to harbor malicious intentions
burden
to implicate/to involve
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
to suffer defeat in every battle (idiom)
to be drowned (figurative and literal)
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to repeat errors/to continue blundering/to make continuous mistakes
to force someone to do something
to sneer at sb/to ridicule
to lose one's standing/to have one's reputation swept away/a complete defeat and fall from grace
to resign oneself to adversity (idiom); to grin and bear it/to submit meekly to insults, maltreatment, humiliation etc
